docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Dr. Ross F. Nigrelli, a marine biologist and world-renowned expert on diseases of aquatic creatures, died of complications of a stroke on Oct. 4 at Southhampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in East Quogue, L.I.

headline.main: Ross F. Nigrelli, 85, an Expert On Disease of Sea Life, Is Dead

docs.snippet: LEAD: Dr. Ross F. Nigrelli, a marine biologist and world-renowned expert on diseases of aquatic creatures, died of complications of a stroke on Oct. 4 at Southhampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in East Quogue, L.I.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Now that the House has passed the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989, the deficit reduction bill designed to avoid automatic spending cuts under Gramm-Rudman, I have some advice for the members of the Senate, where the debate has stalled. If you think that the Federal budget deficit should be reduced, the surest way to accomplish that goal is to shelve this legislation and allow the Gramm-Rudman spending cuts to go into effect next

headline.main: Generic Drugs: Are They as Good as the Original?

byline.original: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The moves by Congress to dismantle expanded health benefits for older Americans would shift most of their medical costs back to the patients, to taxpayer-supported programs and, to a lesser extent, to private employers, health care experts and insurance industry spokesmen say.

headline.main: Change in Medicare Law to Be Costly

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: DURING the last two years, the Soviet Union has carried out changes in the practice of psychiatry, hoping to persuade the World Psychiatric Association to allow it to rejoin the organization. It left the group in 1983 to avoid almost certain expulsion because of charges that political and religious dissidents were being confined in mental hospitals.

headline.main: In the West, The Verdict on Soviet Psychiatry Is Still Out

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE 68-YEAR-OLD CON-gressman was frantic. Long proud of his ability to remember the names, the children's names and even the birthdays of important constituents, he now made embarrassing mistakes. His memory clearly wasn't what it used to be. Devastated, he sought help at a memory clinic near Washington.
